s - inviting aroma of dark fruits , yeast , and lightly toasted bread . caramel and candi sugar give the nose a pretty big sweetness . toasted bread in the background . low alcohol phenols from this dubbel .  m - very light , slightly watery .

it pours a hazy orange with a 2 finger head of foam and has some nice lacing . excellent head retention and lacing retention .  m - little thin for the style o - nice ris , i like the dark fruit tones , just not as `` big '' as others that i prefer
a mildly aggressive pour helped create this beautiful head that had some real staying power .  mouthfeel is ok , nothing to write home about .

appearance : pours with an immense , pillowy head , nearly half the glass at first . this lite tan foam settles very slowly , leaving behind the best lacing i have seen . the lacing on the glass is thicker than the head on some beers .  the body is medium-light with moderately low carbonation .

the ozzy 's epiphany red poured a deep ruby red with an off-white head that left lots of sticky lacing .  very sweet on top of the tongue with lots of chocolate , but very bitter under the tongue . somewhat unpleasant down there , had the tendency to keep it on top of the tongue for the bottle . definitely a dessert beer . extremely flavorful but i could see how this could be a little too much at times . share a bottle , or have a full bottle if you 're feeling decadent .

an instant whiff of freshly sliced granny smith apples escapes .  despite this beer being from two kinds of beverages which bring expectations of intense carbonation , this beverage is not is as intense as you would expect .

served in the new sam adams bl glass , the beer pours a dark brown color with an inch and a half foamy tan head . lacing and head retention is excellent .  first of all , this beer predates the craft beer era . it 's makers brew a tastey brown lager that they call a porter , and they make this delicious pilsner that they call an ale . they were doing this when our fathers were toasting our european heritage with schlitz . it is light bodied , as it should be , and very drinkable . i suppose i can understand that if someone was expecting an ale they might misjudge this beer - but close your eyes , forget your encyclopedeaic knowledge of beer names - and imagine a time in 1975 when the best pilsner on the east coast was called an ale .

best by : 1st week of july g - foster & # 8217 ; s pint a & # 8211 ; fair golden hue with a bit of haziness , stratospheric head with ridiculous lacing that leaves the glass looking like baby swiss .  already thinnish mouthfeel lost even more body as the glass emptied .
fantastic smell w/ many little nuances and the taste is also quite nice edit : as the drink warms up i smelt and tasted more of the orange peel .  m : a sharp tiny bubble fizziness .
a - has a dense off-white head , with dark brown/ black body .  mouthfeel - medium bodied .
style : american amber / red ale glass : flute appearance : bright copper with a fantastically foamy , cream-colored head .  medium bodied , carbonation was a bit too high , fair texture overall .

a - one and a half fingers of light tan head tops a clear , dark ruby body . retention is decent and the head leaves behind a thick layer of lace as it settles .  mouthfeel is too light in my opinion for an ipa .

aroma : a nice belgian yeast nose with the orange and coriander coming through nicely . smells just right appearance : hazy yellow glass with a fluffy white head that laced like grandma .  m : it has a medium body , but feels kind of flat .
s : rich espresso and milk chocolate . t : coffee , espresso , slight dark chocolate finish .  lightly dextrinous and a hair thin in mouthfeel .

smells like candy , looks like a watery brown ale with red streaks . more hops then expected from the smell . like most of the saranac beers i feel this is a little watery . i am surprised they describe this as a `` robust porter . from the smell i thought this one was going to be differnt but it falls victim to the same watered down flavor profile i have come to expect from sarnac .  m- somer orange honey ale is thin with a light carbonation , slight snap of carbonation at the end .

all hops . very floral and piney . taste is very nice . very balanced .  12 oz bottle into a dfh signature glass wow what a mess this beer was . while it looked fairly innocuous in the glass what was hiding in its depths was anything but ... butterscotch . lots and lots of butterscotch . this is where diacetyl men and diacetyl women meet up to have little bastard diacetyl babies . if saranac would change the label to saranac butterscotch porter they would probably have an award winner on their hands because this sure as hell meets that description . in a word ... terrible .

pours a clear amber color with a tremendous 1.25in off-white head which retains wonderfully and sticks to the glass with every sip .  drank it straight from the bottle . smelled clean and fresh . as far as adjunct lagers go , i have nothing to complain about . this was this first time i 've had one without spitting it out , so i give it a thumbs up . it was actually very crisp and clean and possessed no off-flavours .
the pour is jet black with a luxurious , thick , creamy khaki head that sticks around forever .  mouthfeel : unexpectedly thin .

pours dark black , with some brownish higlights . beautiful nitrogen cascade forms a dense tan head , that lasts to the end .  i suppose an islay whiskey drinker might like the novelty of this beer . as a fan of wood aged beer and not of islay whiskey however , i would call this the worst thing i have ever tasted . i was the token beer geek in the group and as such i was the only one to finish the 3 or so ounces of beer in my glass . comments were : `` must be an aquired taste '' , `` aweful '' , `` that 's the worst thing i have ever tasted '' , and dumping the beer down the sink in descending of order preference . well , that being said , i am glad i tried it . it 's important to temper one 's taste for beer with the occasional dog brew .
smell- cherries , cream , chocolate mousse cake ... outrageously delicious aroma . the malts anchor the fresh , fruity nose .  m - 3.0 - oddly pretty good . thin , bubbly , smooth .

the beer - once poured into a goblet - is cloudy and maple brown topped by a huge off-white head .  while the body speaks of a refreshing summer beer ( i.e . thinner than most ales ) , the flavor is very full flavored . lots of white pepper hop with a lighter pale ale malt flavor . really a beautiful beer and as a blonde , this , i believe , is the best i 've ever had .
appearance : four finger shaving cream egg shell white head , amazing retention , deep dark amber color , lots of carb , really great lacing .  m : feels a bit viscous .
sweet complex delicious aroma , everything you want in a tripel .  mouthfeel was light , a bit thin , and alcohol was evident , but not in a good way .

the so dark that it 's almost black liquid , with it 's dark ruby highlights . looks like it 's just drawn , off of a tap .  fits the style of a dubbel . mouth feel is sharp and crisp with an average carbonation level .

this may be one of the most beautiful beers i 've ever seen . color is just a gorgeous golden color .  it 's so much smoother and has much body to it , compared to all the other crap macro out there .

this one started off great ... pours up a very rocky picture perfect schaumkrone !  i like beer and i like banana bread . however i bought this with some trepidation because fruit beers can get too overpowered by the fruit . the aroma was just what it should be ... bananas . not much hops or malt aromas if any . surprisingly the taste was good . no lacing from the lackluster head but bananas was obvious . overall i enjoyed this beer , it was n't a home home run , maybe a stand up triple .

poured into a large tulip glass a clear deep golden with a large blooming white head that took forever to subside.multiple layers of lace left behind.wow what awesome aromas , there is an american twist to this beer no doubt , floral and citric hops all over the place , its perfect as far as iam concerned.dry on the palate with grassy herbal hop notes , light spiced phenols but they dont play a big role.this is quenching and bone dry , i really like it.if all beers of this style were like this i would be a convert , the american craftmanship to the belgian strong pale style in this beer shows thru with great left coast hop flavors.the alcohol lends a little sweetness but its held in check pretty well .  mouth feel is average , possibly a tad thin , but nothing to really detract .

smells awesome . despite the smell , there is almost no sweetness in this brew .  aroma is orange and lemon wedges , sweet and sugary . taste is nicely balanced , lemon zest and pepper for a little kick of spice , but not quite a hefe in the traditional sense . slight bitterness at the end from the hops . nothing to write home about but a very sessionable ale . a solid american wheat ale , a good choice to have while watching some baseball in the summer or at a fourth of july party .

very aromatic with a long nose of resin and flowers . amazing aroma is both spicy and reminds me of fragrant orchids . while this is very rich , it is an interesting example of using big hops with a strong beer .  m-the body is surprisingly thin .

a : beautiful blood orange ale with excellent clarity . single finger falls to a quilt of pretty pink velvet foam .  the mouthfeel is thin and crisp on the palate , which causes a slender puckering , leading to an excellent drinkability .

starting at the top - screw tops are bad . the clarity was exceptional and the mouthfeel was exceptional for the style ( thin ) .  taste matches the smell , plus some licorice as it warms , though it does n't go down as thick as it looks like it would . the 8 % shows off a bit , but in a good way . overall , a by-the-book stout .
a - good two finger white head that stays around one finger throughout the session .  medium to full bodied that goes a little heavy on the carbonation .
a : pretty awesome pour of a deep dark mahogony brown beer topped by a head of tiny bubbles forming a perfect head/beer boundary .  m medium bodied , but nothing special for the style .

looks soooo good . i love how the nitro bubbles flow around inside the glass . crazy that this beer is lighter than bud calorie wise .  m - medium bodied with extremely lively carbonation that is a bit too brisk and prickly .

taking a whiff of it took me to another world smelling all those malty aroma . overall a great buy .  mouthfeel is average and i really do n't have anything more to say about it , except that just as you would with starbucks coffee , you are going to be left with a slightly funky aftertaste on your tongue . its not unpleasant ... its just acidic and totally starbucks .
looks very nice .  m= a little thin on the mouth but nothing too bad .

pour a golden colour brew with a nice big head that persisted for a long time ( i had n't had a great head like this in a long time ) .  closer to light than medium bodied and fairly dry , moderate carbonation , a bit on the rough side . the difference in yeast added more complexity than i expected , but a slightly modified malt bill would probably improve the texture and create something truly impressive .

brilliant clear golden color , a well-formed one-inch white head , and excellent lacing . stunning .  on tap at the brewery 07-10-09 . pours a beautiful dark brown with nice tan head . great looking beer with a really unique aroma dominated with chocolate and orange . would have love to tasted this blind as the aromas were a bit confusing to the senses . pretty well balanced with a nice bitter chocolate finish . my notes are also saying that there was a nice woody aroma and touch of dry wood in the taste , though i 'm not sure how that came about .
it smells delicious . the taste is a good mix of flavors , different from other cherry stouts .  medium-low mouthfeel and low carbonation .

the aroma is a big blast of cassis fruit , really what i want from a fruit beer . i always find these guys just a bit overcarbonated for my taste , leaving them a bit carbonic .  light orange color ... awesome aroma ... just like fresh pumpkin pie out of the oven ... big cinnamon element ... the taste is more subtle than the nose ... nice pumkin flavor also strong cinnamon and some nutmeg ... mouthfeel is light and slightly watery.. decent pumpkin ... i 'd prefer to see it bigger in body with a little more assertive pumpkin taste..still pretty decent overall and a solid seasonal offering .

pours a pitch black , somewhat viscous color with some black raspberry highlights toward the bottom of the glass . a huge , creamy , thick tan head forms . the lacing is so intense , it is almost as if their is a sold veil of protein on the glass that are impossible to see through .  mouthfeel is pleasantly crisp albiet a bit sugary .

appearance- pours dark and almost black . not as thick as many stouts . the head is huge and light brown . however , it pales in comparison to some of the other fine stouts out there as far as taste , but at least it looks amazing .  smells strongly of fresh floral and citrus hops -- it really smells like you 're sticking your nose into some highly-hopped fresh wort -- with the malt body weakly present -- a hint of caramel behind all of those hops . for taste and mouthfeel , it lags behind kona 's castaway ipa .

the nose is wonderful , full of spice with lots of butterscotch and a hint of bazooka bubblegum . and i 'm not a big fan of this style . but this was simply too much banana .  a : it pours a golden color , not quite copper or amber but far from light also slightly cloudy macro , head is thick creamy and firm s : its smells like beer , smells real fresh t : incredable it has a very heavy grain taste that screams fresh off the farm , very bold and yet refreshing at the same time m : this is average , low carbonation and tiny bubbles makes for a wet beer that lets you taste the flavor instead of the co2 d : very drinkable , my rule of thumb is if i can finish a 16oz glass its a good beer , if i cant it sucks ... i finished a full 16oz no prob and crave more , thank god i have 48 more oz that wont go to waste !
pours beautifully showcasing 2 to 3 fingers of white head that settles to a 1/4 '' and stays that way .  mouthfeel is on the thick side with a little more co2 than i like usually .
the liquid is clear ; the colour is black . the rock hard head is high with a fine crater and a deep brown colour . lots of fine lacing .  m - mouthfeel is a little thin .

the appearance is real nice actually - big fluffy slightly off-white head sitting on top of a kinda hazy deep honey colored brew .  carbonation is a tad harsh to start , but mellows half way through .

s- complex . spicy phenolic clove , as well as some orange peel , pepper , and tons of golden , sweet malt . basically , go read the style guidelines in bjcp ... it smells like that . t- and ... ditto to the taste . d- all being said , while this beer is not exactly the definition of a tripel , it is an excellent beer and well worth the money . thoroughly enjoyable .  the carbonation is on the low side . very buttery , sorta nutty but on the watery side . i really like this beer . it 's unique and has some different flavors .
absolutely incredible aromas here , unlike anything i have ever had .  m- high carbonation and light body .
a - golden , red , amber color ; reminded me a bit of a blood orange .  it has a foamy medium light body with a slightly gritty finish .
pitch black with a gorgeous mocha brown head that sticks to the sides and stays there .  feels a little thin and then the dryness is a letdown .

flavor is not quite as good as the aroma , but it is still pleasing - smoky and oily with tones of coffee and molasses .  mouthfeel - lighter than i was expecting from a stout , and somewhat heavily carbonated . drinkability - this would be even higher if slightly less carbonated , but the taste is fantastic .

disappointing s- there 's a real pleasant citrus aroma coming out of this one that absolutely tickles my nasal passages ... lots of orange in this t- the bitterness is strong in this one .  m-is sort of thin , much more than i would expect . d-is very nice .

i have to say , this was definitely a case of expectations exceeding reality . the bottle looks good , the drawn face of rasputin himself cocking a wary eye towards the drinker . the pour was excellent as well . the beer was nothing but inky blackness , with a chocolate head of foam .  i was never a big ipa fan , but damn ... this one is good . my local bodega tends to get random 6-packs of whatever beer ... usually duds , but always affordable , giving me a chance to try lots of random beers . this one came up , and having never seen it before , i got a 6-pack to try out , despite not being a fan of ipas . let me tell you that this one changed my mind . this is a really , really tasty beer , and if you like this style , i encourage you to give it a try if you see it . i could drink like ten of these !
ridiculously overwhelming cigar box aroma .  m - medium-bodied . carbonation lightens it up a bit , but it 's not distracting .

big ol beige head eventually falls to a finger , lots of lacing left . textbook brown ale appearance .  if this was the first baltic porter i 'd tried , it would have frightened me away from the style . i 've had several of the style , so i had a frame of reference , and i found this beer to be quite horrid . then the beer finished with a terrible , sickly sweetness , like some artificial sweetener mixed with a bittering agent . by my third drink , it had grown so intolerable that i could not go any further . from the other positive reviews , i 'd be tempted to think i had a bad bottle , but this really did not strike me as bottle gone bad , just a bad beer .

deep and dark with a light brown head .  smells like corn , tastes like corn . fairly bad , not recommended . you 're better off spending your time and money elsewhere . i did n't really expect much from a guatemalan beer , and it lived down to my expectations .

appearance : the pure hoppiness pours a bright , brilliantly clear yellow-orange-ish color with a nice half-inch head that sticks around for quite some time . a boat load of bubbles continuously rises from the bottom of the glass as well . the lacing is outstanding .  mouth : most prominently smoky and bitter , the fruity entrance of this beer does not meet the expectations set by the complex aroma . also , i would prefer that the beer maintained a more strongly carbonated mouth-feel , but i think that the size of the head ( which remained consistent to the very last glass of the bottle ) uses up a fair amount of the bubbles . a little unbalanced , but over-all an enjoyable 3l celebration .

i poured beautifully amber golden with a large puff of a head that became chunky a left the best lace i have ever seen .  i rarely find a beer that i feel has a good balance of smell , taste , `` mouth after feel '' , feel , drinkability , and overall balance . perhaps a bit over carbonated , the carbonation is the first to hit the mouth , followed quickly by sugary-wheat almost powered taste , as if a ground piece of wheat was poured directly into the batch , matched equally well later on by great coriander , orange , medium grain , and light spritzer flavors .
poured into tulip style fischer glass rapidly to yield a pale yellow body and a good fluffy white head that fills the glass from the 12 ounce serving .  average mouthfeel .

this beer simply smells fantastic . the flavor is dominated by vanilla and chocolate , while bourbon and wood aging have also added their flavors .  this beer seems a bit too carbonated to me , but overall , it just seems too light .

poured with a nice fluffy one and a half inch white head on top of a hazy pale golden straw colored liquid . appears to be pretty well carbonated . head retention is great .  medium bodied with a light oily feel .

pouring a deep amber with a dense , light khaki head with excellent retention and lacing , this is a pretty excellent looking ipa .  pours a opaque black colour with a medium frothy tan head . aroma is creamy with some hints of coffee and chocolate . initial taste is very creamy ( milk shake ) , coffee and some cocoa . minor bitter hops in the finish . great head retention and lacing was slapped around the sides of the glass nicely .
poured a deep brown with purple edges . a good two fingers of very dense mocha foam perched on top of this one .  m - average , balanced carbonation .

the aroma was of floral hops , sweet malt , wheat and hints of wildflowers and citrus . very appealing ! there was a twang from the wheat , understated pilsner malt and an unusual bitterness , especially on the finish , that threw it off .  the carbonation was a little high which was disappointing .

on tap at manbearpigs , i mean manderes a - golden-orange in color with a lot of head , which dissipates slow and leaves a nice lacing . great appearance and smell , no taste .  my only complaint about this beer is the mouthfeel . it 's overly carbonated and as such is quite abrasive on the tongue and washes away all the flavor before you can really enjoy .

some real nice legs and scattered leopard like lacing . no noticeable carbonation , and manages to keep a decent collar , this looks pretty nice .  the flavor is nice , roasted malt , bitterness adds to the chocolate feel and the finish is dry with a slight sour taste . while this brew for me is light in its feel , but all of the irish stouts seem to be , it is a nice and a step ahead of the beamish and murphy 's and seems to be way ahead of guinness . overall this is a great brew , one i would get during the st. patty 's timeframe .

beer on draft at a local beer bar , served as a 0.5 l in a weihenstephaner wheat beer glass . beer is brown and has high haze , can not see through the beer . whitish / brownish head of tight bubbles is present and completely covers the beer ( two fingers thick ) .  very thin for a double stout .
pretty heavy lacing as well .  m : light carbonation with a light body .
the aroma is full of citrus and piney hops .  m - a bit too oily and overcarbonated for the style in my opinion .

a very sessionable beer i 'm happy to find on tap in several establishments down here . pour is a beautiful orange with excellent lacing as i drain the glass .  this continues into a palate that i hoped carried a little more density . while a very nice beer i came out with the feeling that some barrel aging would smooth and fill out the midpalate .
dark caramel brow color with a lasting beige head of fine bubbles .  m- lighter in bodied than i would have guessed .
looks really nice .  medium body with an easy , surprisingly fizzy mouthfeel .

although very pleasing , something is missing from this imperial - it seems uni-demensional ; i would have prefered a slightly more eclectic malt & hop flavor more reflective of the superb aroma . mouthfeel is slightly weak for an double ipa .  poured a deep golden with some orange tint with a thin head but had a nice clear color , aroma was mainly of citrus fruit with some toasted grain , no alcohol aroma wich sometimes might be associated the style but that was to be expected i guess with this crazy law down here.nice flavors going on very malty and pretty sweet but not overly so i picked up some pineapple and some doughy qualities.a lighter version of a spring classic i could spend a day drinking this .
smell is dried fruit coupled with caramel sweetness .  mouth feel was average for the style drinkability was good .
a - appearance is phenomenal - slightly cloudy amber color with a creamy white head and great retention and lacing .  mouthfeel is average for the style .

smell- definitely one of the best smelling ipa 's i have put my nose too . very well balanced though .  carbonation seems a little light and it fits the style well . like this but could use a bit more carbonation .
this is a very nice looking beer , the aroma is on but the alcohol is high , even for an imperial for my tastes .  mouthfeel is medium-low and a little on the carbonated side .

semi-vigorous pour reveals a deep brown ( nearly black ) opaque brew with a beautifully reverse-cascading two-finger head of frothy espresso-colored foam . the head seems to want to linger forever , making the presentation extremely appealing and inviting . flawless .  the carbonation is quite strong with medium sized bubbles ; maybe it is a little bit too strong ?
aroma is of coffee and chocolate malts , with some hoppiness apparent as well .  the only real criticism is that for a summer beer , i expected a little more carbonation to leave my mouth cleaner .

the aroma is powered by clove and hints od spice . the taste is very good , and follows the aroma of clove and spice ... and backed with a heavy abv .  appears heavily carbonated with many bubbles rising to the top . mouthfeel / drinkability - light to medium bodied . second review notes : on-tap once more at 101 laundry .

perfect lacing .  the term gold could be used to describe this lager , but 'gold ' makes it sound valuable so am going to go with 'yellow ' because yellow has more negative conotations associated with it . i suppose the carbonation level and overall body of the beer are it 's saving graces ; though even that is just average .

dark , brownish black , almost opaque . decent lace .  essentially , this is imported bad malt liquor . cidery malt , with an overwhelming fusel alcohol presence . a strong lager can be done well , or , as this demonstrates , very , very badly .
produces a solid three fingers width of a gorgeous pillowy white head .  m = medium bodied , good mouthcoating , carbonation stings the tongue just a little too much .

the presentation was great ; the rolling foam that starts at the bottom and works its way up the glass was awesome . there was no aroma i could detect .  m a little over carbonated but pretty smooth and an easy drink .

nose is wonderfully lager-yeasty , with puffed rice and fresh wet straw .  poured from a bottle into a pilsner a-very deep amber with about a 1 finger head s-malt , barley , bread and spices all come through very heavy in the nose with hints of a sweet fruit or maybe even cinnimon t & m-bready with a very plesant rosted pumpkin seed flavor as well , has a slight hop bitterness in the finish and goes down pretty smooth . d-this is one of my favorite oktoberfest brews and ill have more and more as the time nears .
pours out a nice dark , dark brown , almost no light getting through anywhere . nice tan head rises and sits on top the whole drink .  fizzy and light on the tongue .

the smell was great ! cherries and banana were apparent along with tropical sweet fruits . the taste was almost as good as the smell . bitterness from the hops will be more diminished with time but are a nice addition to the young product .  medium-bodied and moderately carbonated , the flavors throw back to the aroma , with a pronounced hoppiness that is balanced well by a base of biscuity grain .

the copper colored beer has great retention , lacing and carbonation . seeing this beer makes me want to drink it .  m - pretty smooth , thin , a little refreshing , could easily be better ( especially considering i was in one of those `` i could really use a beer '' moods when i poured this ) .
pale golden color with a nice white head .  mouthfeel is a little thin but tolerable.finish is clean .

brewed to celebrate their 21st anniversary , full sail 's `` 21 '' is patterned as a doppelbock with a bright fruity nose and polished auburn color . the flavor reminds me of a chocolate bonbon filled with cherry liqueur .  m-fuller body and grainy on the palate with an assertive carbonation and a semi dry crisp finish .

appearance ; a beautiful , clear amber .  strong berry flavor with an artificial sweetener after-taste . drank like a b & j wine cooler . i drank half and barely finished the rest . if your looking for a good fruit beer id suggest bluepoints blueberry ale or longtrail 's blackbeary wheat .
pours a very dark amber color with a perfect foamy off-white head with good retention .  m : good , not great . i drank one and thought it was on the thinner side .
the aroma was amazing . you could smell tanin and dark cherry . the promise of the smell was compelling and i could hardly wait to taste .  m : oily , not very crisp .

a : pours a beautiful , clear copper body underneath an inch of creamy white head . perfectly gorgeous dipa s : nice hop-forward aroma that showcases pine , along with some tropical fruit , caramel malts , and some alcohol .  the mouthfeel is a bit thin as far as stouts are concerned , but it 's not so watery as to ruin the experience .

the aroma was fantastic , full of fresh citrus .  the quantity of hops seemed very american but the style of hops seemed very european . as much as i enjoyed this beer , i was disappointed by the mouthfeel . it was thinner than i anticipated with a prickly , large bubbled effervescence .
ap= brilliantly clear straw yella color with very quick and abundant bubbles rising .  a little watery at moments in the sip ( light body ) .

pours a slighty hazy pale orange with an inch and a half of off white head . ridiculous retention as well ... when i finished 20 minutes later , there was still a half inch of head sitting in the bottom of the glass .  the mouthfeel let me down a little even though you can tell from the taste that hops arent a big figure in this , its not light and its not lively . there is no attack on your tongue from the carbonation .

black ink in a pint glass . frothy mocha head of a half inch retains itself quite well . thin trace lace .  a- dark brown , almost black body with an off-white head that leaves lots of lacing s- maltiness and chocolate , not a whole lot else t- roasted malts , molasses , toffee , an interesting bitter chocolate finish giving a nice movement to the taste m- medium bodied and a bit too carbonated for my liking but not too bad d- i liked the complexity of this and will revisit it as it really does make me think of the holidays !

the look is awesome , with a dark brown head , about 1/2 inch high , leaving a cap and lace all the way down . darkest head i have ever seen on any beer .  m - a kind of average , standard ( within the class ) smoothness . maybe too much burn .
appearance : beautiful . golden .  it has a good taste but i think the mouthfeel is too thin .

the beer is very hopped up , and the nose on this beer is prodigious . hop oils , hop esters , hop leaves are all present . this beer is excellent in that regard . in the finish there is a pronounced abv throaty burn to the beer .  mouthfeel was a little thin for a stout .

a : clear , light honeyed amber color with over one finger of persistent white foam head . this particular pour was lovely to look at , but left a lingering scorched feeling on the palate .  m : sweet , citrus , malty .

looks wonderful . big , thick , dense , eggshell head fills up the top quarter of my pint glass . a very light amber with plenty of tiny bubbles floating to the top . 5 for appearance , looks great .  mouthfeel is lighter in the body than american ipa 's with nice carbonation levels .
smells great . good balance of hops , yet not bitter at all  pretty smooth and estery.has some yeasty floaties in it too.mouthfeel is standard .

nice off-white head with great retention and lace .  wife loves the weak bland weak beers and she didnt even like this . possibly the most bland version of this style ive ever had . m/d : offered you nothing and in terms of having a few , it was hard enought getting down the part of the sampler .

well this certainly was a big and bold porter . apparently dry hopping makes the beer much more bitter ? i 'm not sure but this was an extremely bitter example of a porter . the body on this beer was very thick imo .  mouthfeel nicely carbonated , a bit lighter body than expected based on the pour but it is not watery by any means .
pumpkin pie , spice , sweetness , nuttiness , caramel , everything awesome !  only quibble is that it seems a little thin , does n't have a lot of oomph or gravitas to it , just the flavor .

custom six pack from ross deli in lakewood a & s : sweet malts , smoky and a bit of caramel , but pretty darn weak smelling . dark , murky red-brown colored beer . thick , foamy tan head that dissolves slowly . o : not a huge fan of this beer , thought that the two other english browns id rated were much better ( majestic nut brown mbc , and samuel smiths ) .  m - definitely leaves some sort of floral feeling in my mouth . a bit dry and juice-like . soft in my mouth as i drink it , but very dry afterwards .
pours a hazy golden orange with a medium creamy head that retains well and laces the glass .  m : the medium body is syrupy and had soft carbonation .
a- a deep , dark black with an absolutely massive orange/brown head that has excellent retention .  m- the mouthfeel of this beer is somewhat thin but the carbonation is pretty much spot on .

paid $ 1.95 for a single at the party source ... the beer pours a snow white start which turns into a light ambered base with a huge snow colored head , perfect 1/2 '' retention and excellent lacing effects on the glass .  4.0 m thin like most porters but i like a bit more body , fullness than this offers .

lots of lavender , like something you 'd get mom for mother 's day . excellent aroma . lavender does n't translate as pleasantly to taste .  medium to light body , lighter as the beer warmed overall a good ipa with 10 % abv .

fantastic aroma with an intnse floral hop presence .  the flavour sees the banana upfront with a refreshing wheat body and crisp finish . my one complaint would be that the body is maybe a tad too light .
had on tap at peekskill brewery a : a really awesome hazy golden yellow .  a little too much carbonation at times .

huge eggshell head .  smelled of raspberries of course , but with a nice yeasty undertone . taste was very sweet , like raspberry pop . we had this as a before-dinner drink , and everyone was pretty happy with it . my mother ca n't believe it 's actually beer . i recommend as a dessert beer or a beer to give people who do n't think they like beer .
s- a very nice vanilla smell mixed with oak and a hint of maple . t- different in a good way .  mouthfeel is somewhat grainy and perhaps a little more carbonated than i 'd like this style to be .

a nice dark brown , nearly black in the glass with a fair bit of medium brown at the edges . two fingers of creamy beige head that slowly recedes to a half centimetre of stable topping .  this beer was very easy to drink , but really most of them are . it had plenty of bite from the hops , which i enjoyed , but it was very well balanced by the sweetness of the malt . i am definitely going to grab a few more . it is worth getting your hands on .
excellent head with impressive ring lace after each sip . dark amber in color and slightly cloudy . good carbonation .  m.light bodied fizzy carbonation .
a : literally the thickest head i 've ever seen , four fingers , and takes forever to die down leaving behind streaks of soapy lace .  the mouthfeel is medium bodied and kind of watery .
a - black with long lasting lacing .  m : medium in body , the carbonation could be a bit higher , and it leaves the mouth with an almost oily texture . definitely coats the mouth .

huge head over a delectable dark mahogany hazy pour covered with a khaki craggy 2 head sticking to the sides like a paint job . while enjoyed , the head scoffs at the notion of sticking to the glass , but hangs in there . this pour has a upside down waterfall of suds that rush up , quickly tapering to a microscopic bubble flow . a+ for head retention .  a bit more carbonated than i tend to like on a stout- and the consistency is a bit more watery than i really like .

s : sweet but heavy in a nice way , floral hay , very floral for a pils . o : very good pils .  taste is malty with a good bitter coffee aftertaste , seems a bit thin and watery though , if it was a bit `` thicker '' it would have been great .

great smell and a good looking beer .  thin for style , but perfectly low carb , quite creamy , with a finish that is tasty , but not in the way of the crazy clinging dank , molasses , and bitter of many fine offerings of this style . i like this , but i could see a lover of some of the major players in this category thinking it is n't thick nor full flavored enough .

the nose is very impressive and surprisingly large , lots of big fruit esters and ( belgian ? a metallic note surfaces as the beer settles . the big fruity/grassy character of the nose really transfers into its flavor , over all balanced , decent pale malt backbone and a dry hop profile , it sports a rather bitter but not offensive aftertaste .  i was hoping for a belgian strong ale with some woody characteristics , but i got whiskey instead . whiskey aromas , vanilla , bubblegum and spicey alcohol mix together in the aroma and is off putting . pretty much the same going on in flavor with vanilla , whiskey , and coriander-like flavors dominating . odd , oily - almost like mescal - flavors made me want to puke . i tried hard to like this since it was a gift and wanted to tell the gifter that i enjoyed it , but i did n't . someone wake me up when this whiskey barrell aging fad runs its course .

pours a cloudy golden straw with about two fingers of thick white head . pretty good retention .  it has too much fizz for the style . roasty roasty coffee notes , the sour/tart makes it different , but grows a bit too much as it progresses , and the carbonation is just too much for what it should be . still , it 's a very good imperial stout overall that i 'm glad i had the chance to have !
it looks pretty with the amber color and plentiful carbonation .  light and a little thin o-great double , one of my favorites

the high sugar content makes this a bit cloying and substantially detracts from refreshment . d - this beer has an amazing odor . after that smell , any taste is a bit of a let down , but definitely more good than bad all around .  there is also almost no after taste to be found ( weird ) mouth-feel : extremely dry with a light bodied feel .

a : its been said before , duvel has maybe the best pour in the beer world . gigantic fluffy head that sticks around forever , but somehow does n't get in the way of your drinking , when you tip the glass .  almost juice ? mouth was bitter , to be expected , but not a strong bitter , washed about like any other average beer . watery . i 'm impressed with the balance with this brew . one time only but sure would be good in place of lagunitas 's other ipa 's .

reviewed 9/25/2008 ( bottle ) : pours a clear , ruby red colored body , with a huge foamy whitish head , frothy and lasting .  f - more than almost any other beer i 've tried , this one leaves a stickiness in my mouth , and makes me quite thirsty .

a : great looking brew ! golden orange with a big foamy white head that does n't want to ever go away , and leaves sticky lacing . constant show of bubbles continues throughout which keeps a good amount of head in tact the entire time .  one of the easiest to drink and one of the most refreshing beers out there . jimmy buffett knows his market ( summer pounder beer ) ! the only complaint i have is that this beer ( along with red stripe & corona ) are way overpriced for the style of beer . if i spend $ 9 a six pack , i 'm buying a craftbrew with high quality ingredients not this type of beer .

the copius , slow bubbling adds to the overall awesome look of this beer .  i even like wild blue , even though that tastes like grape soda instead of beer . it does n't even taste like cider . it tastes a little like sparkling white grape juice and apple juice mixed together with even less of a cheap pilsner . i drank it , and ca n't believe that i did , so i gave it at least a 2 for drinkability .
it was slightly sweet and very inviting . t : the taste was exactly what i thought it would be based on the smell .  still very good though , even if mouthfeel is thinner than i 'd like .
poured from a bottle into a glass , best before 07mar08 a - really great color . decent head , and pretty good lacing .  mouthfeel was medium-thin , with relatively low carbonation .

the beer pours a bright copper hue with large fluffy orange tinted white head foaming up 3-4 cm with a gentle pour . the foam is very creamy in appearance and tightly packed , getting recharged from several active streams of bubbles rising from the bottle of the glass . the first sip reveals an average body with crisp texture and fine tingly carbonation .  341ml bottle poured into pint glass nov1 2010 a dark brown with a light brown head that has decent retention and leaves a partial ring of lace followed by some patches s faint coffee with loads of milk chocolate and the cherry 's there but quite subtle t chocolates a little darker in the mouth and the cherry comes out a little more and just the faintest hint of woody smoke , not completely dry but a little more sugar may have worked well for it m could use some more bubbles and not as thick as the color would imply d overall this ones pretty decent , i 'd drink int again so that says something just enough cherries to have a positive affect any less and it would go unnoticed and anymore and it would take away form the nice chocolate flavors .
appearance : ample lacing , gorgeous colour and plenty of carbonation throughout giving ample head .  this is pretty oily , so i would like a bit more carbonation .

smell is very juicy sweet pineapple with the expected belgian yeast twang of clove and banana . nice sharp bitterness upfront . muddled with a twist of pineapple but any other flavor is kind of muted .  the look was a little weak ( i felt it should have been a bit darker ) and i would have liked a bit more carbonation . the head was a little weak and thin as well . but again , it was the flavour : somewhat strong but not too bitter , and a very nice , somewhat nutty aftertaste which lingered for a little while .

smell : the first most striking smell is that of raspberries and tart fruit . there is more going on in here and there is a certain bit of almost mushroom like mustiness .  the mouthfeel is on the lighter side of medium bodied , as it should be for the style . it is slightly over carbonated for the style though , and that seems to take away from the flavor a little .

looks very nice .  m - not much of an aftertaste because the entire flavor dissipated before i was able to describe it and i have to take another sip . the spiciness lingers a little , but not as long as many belgians . is hidden pretty well ... however there are definitely better beers of this style out there .

the applewood bacon , oak , and beechwood smoke smell incredible . beneath the smoke i find toasted malt . the nose is very clean . overall : a good smoked doppelbock with an incredible aroma .  a little watery in the mouth but not horrible .
overall a great smelling stout . t- coffee is definitely in the taste , but not in the quantity i expected .  mouthfeel was medium with a mild sweetness on the tongue .

wow , dark black body from pour , with a woody smoke brown head that sits nicely . this is exactly what an imperial stout should look like . beautiful complexion .  it is a fairly crisp beer with high carbonation , so it has that going for it .
sweet sugars and the ooze of an over ripe mango sit nicely behind lovely fruit character .  mouthfeel - smooth , although noticeably watery .

glass - tulip a - copper color with lots of fine bubbles rising to the top . it produced about a 2-finger head , kinda fluffy looking , and it had great retention . it left very nice splashy lacing .  the feel is a bit thin .
pours a seriously creamy brown . lots of lacing , frothy head . looks great , dense and inviting .  m : like your average english ale .
a - reddish brown with a one and a half finger head that leaves thick lacing all down the glass .  mouthfeel was unexceptional , and light to medium bodied .

looks like a perfect representation of the style .  chocolate and coffee lead off taste , with raspberry rising up among the hops just before the finish . the raspberry makes a nice accent for the stout , never dominating it . i had feared that this was the beer equivalent of dunking your toast in your morning coffee . no sense of alcohol , perhaps masked by the raspberry . while not watery , i like my imperials to have a bit more viscosity . surpisingly drinkable for an imperial . while i could n't see this as one of my staples , i can see me putting a bottle or three in my weyerbacher mix-it-yourself cases .

the aroma overwhelms the senses . raisins , prunes , whiskey , port , and pure alcohol flood the nose .  the mouthfeel has little flesh and does n't really hold up to the caramel notes from the nose .

dark , mahagony brown with shades of red and a robust off-white head laces nicely .  because the hops and the malt do n't overwhelm you the mouthfeel is light to medium while drinkability is exceptional .

a- poured with a fresh cream-like , off-white 1/2 '' head . the body is a filtered medium amber color . d- goes down super smooth ... almost like a creamy glass of water !  first sip..boom lots of carbination almost too much almost burned my mouth , i didnt like that so i let it sit for a few minutes to warm up and still too much carbination which i did not enjoy at all kind of killed it for me . good beer just too much carb definitely a lot of other imperials out there that are better . check out moylans imperial its a lot more satisfying .

dark , murky brown color with a huge head of fluffy , tan foam . the head stays for a good while before leaving copious amounts of lacing stuck to the glass and swirling around the surface .  m/d : has a bitter mouth feel that dries it out quickly so it is not the best for drinking on a hot day or to quench a thirst but all in all a great session beer that has amazing taste and smells and i really want this one again .

nose is incredibly complex . soaring notes of rum , wine , clove , orange rind , raisin , and a touch of roasty malt . great very fine mouthfeel , but not particularly long .  a little thin bodied , a little too much alcohol in the finish .

reviewed 12/12/2006 ( bottle @ west alabama ice house , houston , tx ) : ( could n't rate the appearance very well ) very malty then very very hoppy aroma . bitter hoppy taste , but mellows at the end .  the body is bit on the thin side , but that 's not necessarily out of the ordinary for an oatmeal stout .
pours picture-perfect with tall , clinging tan head and dark body ( black unless held to the light .  m : does n't feel to heavy on the pallet , a bit to much carbonation .

ar : unique , spicy/earthy hop , berries , grapes , honey/light caramel , light alcohol , resin , earthy/funky hop , i like it but it might not work in a lot of beers , *grassy ap : beautiful mousse-like light tan head , great retention , clear copper , lace t : spicy , earthy , resinous , unique fruitiness , grape , berries , blackberry , dried fruit , pale malt , crisp , light plum , light citrus , complex unique fruit , difficult to describe , grassy hints , resin and fruit with hints of tart , grape juice with a small amount of cranberry , very lightly vegetative , *pine , *restrained belgian yeast m : high peppery carbonation , medium smooth/creamy mouthfeel , resinous pleasant end , light alcohol o : i wonder what the yeast character is like , interesting , unique , fantastic , very distinct , *tastes fairly fresh , *aggressive hopping *=ideas from fellow taster  smells and tastes sorta like a coffee i once had , nutty ( ? ) i want to say . anchor porter is very unique to me ... of course this my first time having a porter . at first i thought i would n't want to drink a healthy amount of this , but then the beer just grew on me . it was soon goin ' down great . i would gladly drink again .

at first all you see is black with almost no head but then you start seeing the downward flowing bubbles and mysterious swirls of tan and amber as the head slowly forms into a tan masterpiece . although it looks black it is light and non filling .  mouthfeel - slightly effervescent .
a - poured out of the bottle with a fantastic head , some of which remained throughout the pint . lacing was fantastic also .  mf & d- thin bodied and well carbonated .

this beer is nearly black . you know how you can tell a beer has a nice head ? when it is 2 inches high when you pour it , and there is still 2 inches of head in the bottom of the glass when you finish .  mouthfeel - 3.0 moderately carbonated , reasonably smooth , nothing to complain about here .

good head retention & average lacing s : coffee , toasted grain , & some chocolate , mostly espresso notes t : coffee , toasty gain , a bit iron & nice chocolate notes . nice dryness as this warms .  i poured a 12 ounze bottle into a pint glass and immediatly noticed the beautiful color and head . the heaed left much lace which was nice and sticky . there was a stong hop aroma and a strong hop taste . neither was overpowering and both were artfully crafted and mixed . do n't drink and review .
poured from a bomber into a tulip . pours a dark black with chocolate milk colored head .  m : gently creamy carbonation , perhaps a little thin overall .

billowing head grows ever skyward above liquid shining like light copper penny ... heavy malts and a hint of soy sauce in the nose , a bit sweet heavy beery flavor , a profile of multi grain artisan bread , with some american macro lager brew qualities to it as well .  the mouthfeel was lackluster , probably because this bottle had plenty of time to sit .

ok retention but i was messy on my pour , good lacing ... despite my sick stuffy nose i 'm instantly hit with wonderful citrus aromas , orange peel , citrus acid , laced with strong undertones of pine resin . ca n't get any better than this for an ipa ... the taste loses a lot of the orange , i 'm slightly disappointed about that .  smells of buttery pumpkin , spices , and hints of vanilla t- sweet and spicy , with a hint of vanilla in the finish m- very little carbonation . smooth and slightly heavier than i had expected .

a - orange/amber with nice sticky white head .  i took my first sip and was shocked , this tasted totally like an ipa . seemed overly carbonated and gassy . 21st amendment is a great little pub and they have a fine addition to their solid line up with this one .

awesome aroma of floral , hoppy goodness . soft-citrus and other fruity esters with an edge of cotton-candy or bubblegum . complexly fragrant nothing screams at you individually , but theres no mistaking some serious dry-hopping is going on but in a balanced way . caramely sweetness is candy-like and the darkish malts lend an unexpected chocolately character which im not sure im digging .  moderately carbonation a bit too strong for my taste - better on tap .

pours a clear red with a light pink head .  toasted grains , coffee , somewhat sweet and not a bad nose for a porter , the start mostly malt , the top rather thin . finish has a mild acidity , the hops perky in their spiciness , very dry and long lasting aftertaste , overall a fair to middling porter .

pours jet black with a dark brown foam crown . exhibits moderate lacing when swirled .  only complaint is that it seems overcarbonated , and too foamy and tingly . other than that , a very nice beer .
pours a very clear amber red , big light tan head that stuck around for some time and left tons of lacing .  m - a little more thin than i would like with a little lack of carbonation .

the pour is nearly a thing of beauty . body is pitch black . the head is just barely off white and skies up a few fingers with good retention and quite a bit of lacing . each swirl creates three layers -- black up to a mix of brownish-black bubbles and then the white head . really pretty . from there , downhill .  the was a little too thin for my liking , but this is typical of most terrapin stouts .

no lacing or head retenton s : sweet malt & apple skin , big-time fruittyness t : bready with apple skin ( yeast ) notes up front .  when my friends and i sampled the whole assortment of cheap beers , this was the one we settled in with as our most purchased variety . it was the most tolerable , easiest to drink cheap without `` bad beer face '' , and produced the least amount of hangover effects . i have on occassions tried this beer over the 20 years since college and still find this beer in particular to be one of the easiest cheap beer to drink without any bad taste . i 've tried pabst a few times and struggle to finish them because it actually tastes `` bad '' flavor . sure natural light lacks any strong flavors compared to a high-end ipa , porter , imperial stout etc ... but compared to its equivalent price-marked competitors its one of the best choices you can make .

poured with a fantastic foamy frothy sudsy white head and lots of clumpy lace .  mouthfeel was medium , not terribly oily and almost chewy . it 's maybe a bit to cloying and sticky for my liking but all-in-all a decent , well-balanced brew .
pours a pitch black color with a thick brown head into my glass . very good presentation for the style .  m : medium with a little creaminess and some oil .

mouthfeel : super thick , creamy , sticky with medium-low carbonation overall : great smell , but the pure , burning ethanol is too much present for me in the taste .  taste : higher carbonation than most stouts and some extra bitter roast coffee notes .
a : the appearance is phenomenal : a semi-hazy orange hue topped with a fluffy , steamed-milk quality head that laces the shit out of the glass .  mouthfeel a little heavy , with medium carbonation .
overall : smells amazing but does n't follow up on the taste , it 's not very well carbonated but is still very drinkable .  mouthfeel : lots of carbonation , feels light and airy .

the aroma of this brew is a pleasing mixture of oak , vanilla and sweet smelling bourbon . the bourbon provides a nice accent to the base boozy quality . the smell becomes a little dirty and earthy as it warms up with a spicy and fusel kick of alcohol .  well carbonated , a bit prickly at times . drinkability : a reasonably complex , enjoyable brew , though , for my tastes , the carbonation was just a bit too high .

the smell is of caramel , dark cherry and prune .  the carbonation becomes a liability to the weight and texture , which go up in bubbles before i can get a bead on them . some of my fellow bas have been unnecessarily critical of the unique carbonation level rather than seeing it for what it is .

poured from a bomber into a duvel tulip a- pours a dark , clear shade of amber with a solid offwhite head that sticks around for awhile and leaves some excellent lacing . looks gorgeous .  m - i did feel violated , but i wo n't press charges , officer .
pretty good retention . looks very inviting .  m - carbonation is a little too zesty for my liking .

pours a hazy dark golden orange with a creamy off-white head that retains well and laces the glass .  m- very clean with a good amount of carbonation . it does build on the palate a little bit , which i found odd considering how thin this beer was .

great retention and lacing , with bubbles constantly fizzing up to join the cause at many different points around the perimeter of the glass . very dark brown body .  a little rough going down , but over all very nice .

a : this is a dark amber/orange color . it pours with a large white head that has good lace and retention .  bottle poured into st. bernardus chalice three finger head murky gold in color , off white head s : spices , belgian yeast , and phenols t : lemongrass , spices , coriander , and much more m : okay , i 've had better tripels , this seemed too thin .

s : significant hop aroma . definitely , cascade hops as advertised ! i personally like cascade hops so that 's a plus in my book . checked the website and they confirmed it is dry hopped . t : definite bitter hop note with floral , pine , and citrus notes -- again cascade hops . not much malt sweetness to counter act the hoppiness .  m - this one coasts all the way down .

brown lacing atop a jet black brew .  the mouthfeel was not as great as i had hoped it would be , i really would like to taste this beer on draft . reminds me of guinness , but with a richer taste and more carbonated .
it has a wonderful beige head and tight lacing that is frothy . the body is a hazy gold with lots of small carbonation bubbles .  mouth feel is fairly light with light carbonation .

a : this is a beautiful looking beer .  i had this year 's version at the brewpub and while it is not as good as great lakes ' christmas beer or sn celebration , it is still a very good beer . you can really smell the cinnamon and taste the blend of malts and spices . if you are in the toledo area it is worth the stop at maumee bay brewing co. for a pint or three or maybe a stop at the andersons or other store for a bomber .

what an amazing nose ; i 'm getting big notes of acid-sour , cherry , band-aid and even some impressions of hermes luggage . t - the taste is pretty nice , but not as dynamic as the nose . d - other than the rarity , pretty damn drinkable .  malt in the nose ... malt in the taste . caramel shitty malt . yes i sound angry . it borders on barleywine , which is the worst beer style ever .

looks great ! s : has a fairly weak smell , mainly hoppy pine scents .  smell : corny , grainy a little bit of lemon and grass , very little hoppiness taste : taste follows nose , bland and unexciting mouthfeel : goes down really smooth , i wish there was a little more thickness but it 's ok all in all this is an ok beer for the price but imo labatt is the best cheap beer around .

solid malt nose too . great balance in the aroma . t - does n't totally match the aroma but still damn good . bitter , piney , dry , citrus , pine .  m : smooth , not as robust as i would like in a ris , a little thin , pretty average . d : the lessened mouthfeel adds to the drinkability , making this probably the most drinkable ris that i 've ever had .

smell is musky and fruity like peaches on the verge of being over ripe . aromas of peach , plum , fig , raisin and grapes . strong oak wood aroma here . i am sure that there are those who do n't like the smell of maturing wine in barrels but i sure do and that gives this beer a bit of a plus in the aroma category .  the taste comes on mildly hoppy at first , but sweetens in the middle , possessing an almost carmel-like overtone . the finish is clean and refreshing . i would consider this a fine session beer for a hot , sunny day .

s : dark chocolate , bitter , with just a little bite from the alcohol . still good , and i bet it could make some killer half and halfs .  as others have said , this is very reminiscent of an ipa , the aroma of fresh hops and pine are similar to that style . this brew has an amber color and when poured from a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass creates a nice white head . the taste is very refreshing and seems like a fabulous brew to have on a hot summer day . i could , and would like to , drink this again . too bad i can never find it .

's appearance : deep and dark with glints of toffee around the edge . two fingers of off white head slip down to a touch of sticky lacing .  the body is medium-light with medium carbonation , and could benefit from being a touch heavier so that it boosts the flavour even more , but its okay as it is .

the aroma is the highlight of this beer , being nice and hoppy . very clean and citrusy , with a definite vegetal character , you can tell this thing was just loaded with dry-hops . the combination is really quite balanced , although ending on an uncomfortably bitter note with just a ton of booze . the boozy finish is unsettling and i maybe would prefer it to be a little dryer and a little less sweet and the bitterness is a little harsh and lingering .  mouthfeel seems dominated but a fast carbonation , over a thin to medium liquid .

aroma of rich earthy chocolate cake , vanilla , dark malt and a hint of hops . smells rich . taste is surprisingly balanced .  the body was cloudy and a deep yellow color . the off white head and lace was very creamy . this might have been the sweetest flavored weizen i had ever tasted . it was very banana like and a bit of bubble gum to it . as with all of their beer though i did find it to be thin .

s : wow . hops ! very bold smells . d : i think this thing was too hoppy without enough malt to balance it nicely .  this is well-done and a clear american classic , but the mouthfeel seemed a little thin and i think the beer could have been a tad more aggressive wrt maltiness and/or malt complexity without hurting the smoke profile at all .

poured out of a 500ml bottle into a wheat glass . pours out golden yellow with a thick creamy head that is fluffy like soap suds . carbonation is lively as it should be in a wheat beer . head laces the glass very well .  a : golden straw/amber hue , passes lots of light , nice white head , mild lacing s : strong bourbon , vanilla , malty t : vanilla , bourbon , mild caramel m : decent carbonation , light to medium bodied , watery overall , this beer has a great nose and taste .

pours a deep brown with an exceptional head .  the body is moderately light and mouthfeel is clean . the beer is not brewed with corn and it 's good for another 10 months so i do n't know what the problem is . i expected a helles with less body and malt flavor , but what i got was a corny mess . i ca n't imagine why they would even sell this beer .
a : liquid black gold , great head , with good retention , amazing after all it was a cask , it looked soild black , and i barely let the light pass through the glass ! !  mouthfeel : medium-bodied .

poured like heavily used motor oil with large , lasting two finger tan head .  hints of raisins & toast with a dry , fruitty ( dates ) finish mf : a bit sharp with a little too much carbonation drinks fine , just a little too young ( i think )

pours a deep copper breadcrust mixed nicely with volcanic bubbles ascending to the surface . about one and a half finger head with a thick foam .  m : light to medium body . medium level of carbonation .

it has a dark brown , near black , with a hint of red . the head is thick and lasts long , plenty of lace also . the looks sets your brain for something better , thus the whole experience is dissapointing , however it works as a `` light '' beer , if i may say .  mouthfeel is average , medium body and on the crisper side with the finish .

a-pristine amber beer , showing high carbonation . slightly off-white head retains well while being constantly replenished by the streams of carbonation bubbles ; remains as a thick layer through the whole drink .  a bit thin , imo .
absolutely lovely pour .  the mouthfeel was a bit weak for the style .

a - opaque brown black with a small coffee head and good lacing s - tiny bit of a coffee scent but not much t - malt with a little coffee .  the mouthfeel is smooth , but a bit lacking in the carbonation .

poured into a tulip glass . amazing lacing along sides of glass : sheets , lines , and clumps abound .  mouthfeel : nice mouth-coating , but a much weaker carbonation than i was expecting ( the tap ? ) .

outstanding aromas ! it smells like christmas , they totally nailed it !  extremely mild , even for an english style , however it had an interesting coffee finish , which i do n't think i 've ever found in a nut brown before . particularly curious , since the malts were not all that roasted . hmm .

pours a hazy golden orange amber with a huge creamy off white head that retains well and laces the glass .  taste : a true witch 's brew of vegetables , raspberry punch , and a thin maltiness . finishes tart and watery . mild carbonation .
a very comlex aroma of sweet malt , coffee , brandy , sasparilla , and a distinct woodiness . wow . i am not getting any pumpkin or yam .  medium bodied with an oily texture .

reviewed 1/1/2009 ( bottle ) : pours a hazy yellow color body with a humongous craggy white head , very lasting .  my main complaint is the mouthfeel , which is a little lacking given the style . a porter should be a little bit thicker , with more substantial body .

12oz bottle to tulip . wow , this is one awesome looking beer . a beautifully dense head capping a brew that is the deepest of amber , with a shine that would make any ruby gemstone jealous . stunning .  pours really great , decent aroma for a porter , nice head and lacing , but the taste seems to be a little off ... but in retrospect the flavor is ok. enigma ... what the hell . seems like i got kicked in the head by a pack of wild hyenas , and then my throat got ripped out by a flock of roaming vampires and then my essence was drained by a murder of migrant tigers . weird stuff .

poured from the 750ml brown bottle into a wine glass the poured yielded a beautiful 2 finger , fluffy , white head atop a light brown colored beer . streams of carbonation bubbles ran up the glass and generous spots of lace stuck to the glass throughout the sample .  nice ... mouthfeel : somewhat dry and crisp , but the body is 'way ' too thin for an oatmeal stout . they should thicken it up for a more chewy mouthfeel .
thick , healthy crop of rocky light beige head is erected on top . the retention and lace abilities are very good .  mouthfeel : this beer kind of dries out my mouth .

admittedly i 'm a sucker for raspberries , so for me this aroma is to die for . the nose is predominantly raspberries , soft and creamy in texture , no real tartness . as much as i adore raspberries , the flavour tends to not live up to what it advertises with the above two categories . definitely not up to par with what unibroue has capably proven to us in the past of what they can accomplish .  mouthfeel is decent , but the carbonation is way too pronounced , very fizzy and bubbly .

this beer was brilliantly clear golden honey with tiny , active carbonation . the head was creamy and dense and left clingy foam in the glass .  medium dark lager yellow color with a smallish head that disappears rather quickly . aroma is a little soapy with pumpkin pie spices ... like from a can . flavor is pure pumpkin pie spice powder without the pumpkin meat . just spice sprinkled over a malt beverage . there are much more complex and genuine tasting pumpkin beers out there .
